title: Salem Area History - Sample Tour
body:
Oregon State Capitol
900 Court St. NE
Salem, OR 97301
503-986-1388
www.oregonlegislature.gov
Recommended Time Allotment: 1 hour
Marble adorns Oregon's Capitol built in 1938. Atop the dome sits the "ÏGold Pioneer"ù. Tours of the building and tower are available, call for times.

Willamette Heritage Center
1313 Mill St. SE
Salem, OR 97301
503-585-7012
www.WillametteHeritage.org
Recommended Time Allotment: 2 hours
Willamette Heritage Center preserves three 1840's Mission houses and a 19th century woolen mill; the Museum interprets Western Oregon's settlement and industry. Visit Oregon's American Treasure.

Lunch and Shopping.
Historic Downtown Salem.
Roughly bounded by Chemeketa, High, Ferry, and Front Streets.
Recommended Time Allotment: 2 hours
Visitors appreciate historic downtown's beautiful architecture, mix of delicious eateries, unique shops, art galleries, salons, and major department stores. Entertainment and walking tours available (self-guided).

World Beat Gallery
189 Liberty St. NE, #211B (Located inside Reed Opera House)
Salem, OR 97301
503-581-2004
www.salemmulticultural.org
Recommended Time Allotment: 30-45 minutes
Cultural exhibitions from Salem's ethnic communities displayed all year.  2010 themes include Samoa, India, international marriage customs and winter holidays around the world.

Historic Elsinore Theatre
170 High St. SE
Salem, OR 97301
503-375-3574
www.ElsinoreTheatre.com
Recommended Time Allotment: 1 hour
Enjoy a performance or classic film in Salem's restored 1926 vaudeville theatre. From "ÏBach to Rock"ù and "ÏBroadway to Ballet"ù the Elsinore has it all.

Bush House Museum/Salem Art Association
600 Mission St. SE
Salem, OR 97302
503-581-2228

Charles Humble joined the Oregon Wine Board staff in 2011 from a successful career in communications consulting at several agencies in the Portland area. In his current position, he is responsible for all internal and external OWB communications as well as all online and interactive communications. During his tenure at OWB, he has established a strong track record of communicating the successes and opportunities of the Oregon wine industry.

His accomplishments have included producing the winning bid for the 2012 Wine Bloggers Conference held in Portland in 2012. He also orchestrated the communications plan that turned the media environment for the 2011 grape harvest from negative to positive with a focused and hard-hitting campaign that was dubbed "the miracle harvest."

He is a graduate of Linfield College in McMinnville, OR, where he earned a degree in communications. He was a journalist at several Oregon daily newspapers, including the Albany Democrat-Herald, Oregon Journal and The Oregonian before joining the public relations profession.

He was president and CEO of Insync Communications in Portland before the agency was acquired by Waggener Edstrom Worldwide where he was an executive vice president. Charles resides in Vancouver with his wife, Lynne. His hobbies include wine, sports, reading, running and technology.
